'Intersubjective verifiability' is the capacity of a concept to be readily and
accurately communicated between different individuals ("intersubjectively"), and
to be reproduced under varying circumstances for the purposes of verification.
It is a core principle of empirical, scientific investigation. Philosophy of Mind. Jaegwon Kim. 2005. Westview Press, p. 75. (ISBN

Although there are areas of belief that do not consistently employ
intersubjective verifiability (e.g., many religious claims), intersubjective
verifiability is a near-universal way of arbitrating truth claims used by people
everywhere. In its basic form, it can be found in colloquial expressions, e.g.,
"" or "." The scientific principle of replication of findings by investigators
other than those that first reported the phenomenon is simply a more highly
structured form of the universal principle of intersubjective verifiability.
headings: Intersubjective verifiability versus belief based on faith
